reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 2. EU development policy and practice

description.narrative: This work stream aims to support European actors to formulate and implement coherent and integrated policies to tackle global challenges (SDGs, 1, 2, 8, 10, 16, 17), by contributing to:1) Better politically contextualised EU international and development cooperation policy and practice; (e.g. more effective use of political analysis in policy and programming);2) More evidence-based EU development policy making (e.g. effective uptake of evaluations, evidence-based, specialised research etc); 3) EU development policy is better integrated in EU external action / EU Global Strategy implementation and European development diplomacy is more effectively utilised (e.g. more effective synergies between EU development policy and practice and other external action domains to pursue global public goods, Europe develops capacities to use development diplomacy);4) More effective collaboration between EU institutions and EU member-states at HQ and field levels (e.g. Joint programming, joint implementation) ;5) Reduced gap between EU development policy and its implementation (e.g. programming of financing instruments reflects the MFF ambition to be more strategic and political and is is based on sound context analyses and rooted in country realities) ;6) Key African and EU stakeholders are better informed on content and processes to engage effectively with EU institutions (e.g. African and European actors are increasingly aware about EU development policy discourse and better enabled to engage with the EU at critical moments, with the right information); 7) More effective multi-actor engagement driving change in EU development policy and implementation (e.g. Change agents MS, EC, Civil Society, Parliament, African institutions, Africa civil society engaged, working for change and treated with appropriate levels of respect).

description.narrative: Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2017-01-01 - 2018-06-30

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

The EU’s external action overarching policy framework has been updated in recent years (EU Global Strategy in 2016, New European Consensus on Development in 2017). ECDPM provided inputs in both processes. The challenges have increased and are seriously putting the response and adjustment capability of the EU to the test. The 2030 Agenda on sustainable development, new global dynamics as well as numerous crises that have emerged and persist in the EU’s neighbourhood and beyond, have significantly transformed the international environment within which EU development policy and practice takes place. Against this background, ECDPM has confirmed its position as the “go-to” think tank within Brussels on EU development policy issues. The Centre received many requests to present its analysis and facilitate discussions, particularly on the political and technical details that are difficult to master but essential for progress. Influential stakeholders call on ECDPM for analyses and for facilitating policy dialogue. EU institutions and member states use the Centre’s publications, events and advice. So have civil society and others as they seek to grasp and shape the issues at stake. Over the past couple of years, ECDPM has reached out to policy-makers in all EU institutions (Commission, Council, Parliament) and significantly contributed to supporting European actors to formulate and implement coherent and integrated development and foreign policies, including around the EU budget process (see below). During this period, our work has mainly focused on better politically contextualised EU development policy and practice (outcome #1), more evidence-based EU development policy making (outcome #2), better integrated EU development policy in EU external action (outcome #3), more effective collaboration between EU institutions and EU member-states at HQ and field levels (outcome #4), and more effective multi-actor engagement driving change in EU development policy and implementation (outcome #7). One of the main areas of work for which there has been the preparation of the next EU budget (the Multiannual Financial Framework - or MFF - for the period 2021-2027, including the future generation of EU External Financing Instruments), for which there was a strong demand. We focused on the design, content and functioning of a broad instrument for EU external action. The centre has carried out substantial analysis and produced a special ‘dossier’ page (http://ecdpm.org/dossiers/multiannual-financial-framework-mff/) on our ECDPM website bringing together all our work related to the MFF to enable easy and direct access to our knowledge on this critical issue. We published seven blog posts, one discussion paper and one briefing note. Our leading role in the preparation of the “Coherence report” which drew strategic insights from the external evaluations of the External Financing Instruments has enabled us to develop our analysis based on solid ground and contribute to more evidence-based EU development policy making. Our publications highlighted the strategic political and technical choices that should be made in the MFF in view of aligning the EU’s global aspirations, resources and financial instruments, thus ensuring that EU development policy is better integrated in EU external action. In particular, our work led to the first questioning of strategic decisions in the public domain and an event with all the EU stakeholders held at the Swedish Permanent Representation in Brussels. In addition our paper on “Organising the next EU budget for external action – A ‘single’ instrument?”, published in December 2017 (six months ahead of the Commission proposals) set the scene and kickstarted the debate in Brussels around the proposed merger of several instruments for external action and development cooperation, which is now at the core of the negotiations of the €123 billion proposed EU budget Heading for “Neighbourhood and the World”. These contributions have received positive feedback, and we continue to receive many invitations and requests that illustrate the relevance and quality of this work, which has also been quoted in various media. We have participated in numerous formal and informal events in Brussels and in EU member states where background work was being done to formulate positions, allowing us to reach out and disseminate our analysis more effectively to a broad range of decision makers in all EU institutions (Council - Committee on Development, European Parliament, European Court of Auditors), Foreign Ministries (Ireland, Sweden, Belgium), implementing stakeholders and civil society more widely. In doing so, we have contributed to a better politically informed and contextualised debate on the main implications and strategic choices at play in the MFF negotiations for a better integrated EU external action. We have also contributed to empowering key stakeholders to engage effectively with EU institutions in the negotiation process (for instance, by explaining the main issues at stake to civil society networks outside Brussels, or to non-usual suspects such as the European Court of Auditors). The Centre also focused on more effective collaboration and coordination between the EU institutions and member states (outcome area #4). This is also a key part of implementing both the EU Global Strategy and the EU Consensus on Development. The aid/development effectiveness agenda has lost political traction in recent years. Therefore, our work has been more in a research phase during the first year with less outputs. Yet we explored how to move the debate forward, notably by looking at the incentives and disincentives, practical obstacles and recent opportunities for more joint work in the area of development cooperation. Building on our past work on joint programming, we scoped other recent policy initiatives that are attracting high political attention such as the EU Trust Fund for Africa, or the Sahel Alliance. Such initiatives hold potential for enhancing coordination and joint action, particularly in situations of fragility and protracted crises. ECDPM was the first to assess these initiatives from that angle. We have spoken to and interviewed many institutional and non-governmental stakeholders, in Brussels, member states and in partner countries. We captured the need to study more closely experiences of coordination at field level, with a view to better understanding how to reduce the gap between policy and implementation when it comes to EU coordination and joint action. Future work will also focus on the preparation of the next EU (joint) programming process of development assistance which offers further opportunities for more effective collaboration between EU institutions and EU member-states at HQ and field levels. Our work has contributed to a more ‘honest’ debate on these issues. We have also looked at how the EU can improve its engagement with middle-income and more advanced developing countries, including beyond development cooperation. ECDPM has published two blog posts and a discussion paper pointing to the current gaps in the overall policy and financing framework and potential areas for improvement. The paper is the most comprehensive analysis of the EU and MICs/MADCs currently available and also looked at innovative ways for cooperating with such countries. Our analysis has been picked up and referred to by a wide range of influential EU stakeholders and will help the agenda setting in this relatively undefined area of EU development policy. It has also positioned ECDPM as the ‘go to’ agency for independent analysis on this topic, just at a time when the EU is beginning to think more specifically how MICs and MADCs will feature in the next MFF. It is likely that if the EU does produce a specific policy on middle-income countries and more advanced developing countries (MICs and MADCs) it would be in no small measure related to our work in this area and it could well incorporate ideas. Yet it is too early to tell. Overall, building on its longstanding expertise and network, ECDPM has significantly contributed to feeding into ongoing EU policy processes aimed at making EU engagement with the rest of the world more effective and strategic.

description.narrative: Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2018-06-30 - 2020-12-31

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

One of the main areas of focus was to feed into the debate and negotiations on the next EU’s long-term budget for the period 2021-2027 - the so-called Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) - including strategic discussions on the future EU External Financing Instruments, notably the proposed Neighbourhood Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI). The MFF negotiations constitute a unique opportunity to shape the framework and resources for EU policies, including for EU external action. They notably determine the focus of funding streams (the instruments) and available amounts for EU international and development cooperation with Africa.In 2019-2020, ECDPM continued to reach out and disseminate its analysis to a broad range of decision makers in all EU institutions and several member states as they were preparing their own positions on the MFF and NDICI. As negotiations on the overall MFF became more ‘political’ at European Council level, and linked to broader budgetary dynamics, ECDPM continued to produce short analysis on the potential impact of budget cuts for external action.Looking forward, ECDPM continued to link its work on MFF/NDICI with the upcoming ‘programming’ process of EU resources for international and development cooperation for the period 2021-2027. Following a first scoping paper in 2018, ECDPM participated in events, trainings and produced further analysis on the strategic programming of the NDICI.In 2020, the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic significantly affected EU processes and led to a radical reprioritisation of EU development policy and resources to support developing countries with the immediate impact of the crisis. ECDPM was very reactive and among the first to produce analysis of the EU global response to COVID-19 (https://ecdpm.org/publications/challenge-scaling-up-european-union-global-response-covid-19/), including on the role of development finance institutions therein and the newly proposed Team Europe approach. Furthermore, ECDPM also produced analysis on the EU as a global health actor (https://ecdpm.org/publications/fit-purpose-eu-role-global-health-era-covid-19/) as the topic gained importance.It is difficult to draw a direct line from outputs to outcomes to overall impact, but through our active contribution to the debate and discourse on Heading 6 of the EU budget/MFF, we made a significant contribution to policy thinking and evidence on EU development policy and beyond. Our work on the EU MFF process and NDICI has notably allowed us to contribute to a better politically informed and contextualised debate by inputting high-quality, evidence-based and relevant analytical work into restricted and public policy discussions at critical moments of the MFF negotiations.The products and the thinking produced were of high quality, widely read and generated useful and challenging debates in EU development and foreign policy circles, ultimately leading to better policy discussion and decision making. We have been invited into internal briefs as experts by EU member states, civil society networks and the EU parliament (https://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/events/events-hearings) while producing knowledge in the public domain and offering insights used by all the major players. We participated in numerous formal (https://ecdpm.org/events/development-neighbourhood-cooperation-post-2021-mff/) and informal events in Brussels and in EU member states (https://ecdpm.org/events/priorities-europe-multiannual-financial-framework/) as organisations and institutions were preparing their own positions, allowing us to reach out and disseminate our analysis more effectively to a broad range of decision makers in all EU institutions (Council - Committee on Development-CODEV Informal, European Parliament, European Court of Auditors), Foreign Ministries (Ireland, Sweden, Belgium, Finland), implementing stakeholders and civil society more widely.ECDPM published several blogs to inform on the advancement of the overall MFF negotiations and continued to make a strong case for protecting external spending in the EU budget: Can the new European Commission be truly geopolitical, innovative and flexible without the right amount of money? (https://ecdpm.org/talking-points/can-new-european-commission-be-geopolitical-innovative-flexible-without-right-amount-money/) First thoughts on the EP elections and development policy (https://ecdpm.org/talking-points/first-thoughts-european-elections-development-policy/), The state of the negotiations on the long-term EU budget after summit ends with black smoke (https://ecdpm.org/talking-points/state-negotiations-long-term-eu-budget-after-summit-ends-black-smoke/). In July 2020, European Council cut the European Commission’s 2018 Heading 6 proposal by 10%. While disappointing, this is significantly less than several other budget headings and increased, although slightly (2%), the funding for external action when compared with the MFF 2014-2020 despite Brexit. While, of course, we recognised that it was a combination of actors and interests that led to this outcome, we feel that our work helped those willing to make a case to protect external resources from cuts.ECDPM was one of the first think tanks to produce analysis of the programming of EU resources for international and development cooperation for the period 2021-2027. In 2019-2020, ECDPM presented and engaged with various stakeholders, and produced a research paper (https://ecdpm.org/publications/necessary-shake-up-eu-programming-international-cooperation/) looking at how programming can be harnessed to make EU external action more consistent and innovative in aligning with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the EU’s external action objectives. The paper was quoted on capacity4dev (https://europa.eu/capacity4dev/joint-programming/discussions/ecdpm-report-necessary-shake-eu-programming-international-cooperation), presented and discussed with EU institutions and representatives of EU member states (https://ecdpm.org/events/upcoming-development-programming-finnish-presidency/) as well as at the European Parliament (https://www.europarl.europa.eu/doceo/document/DEVE-OJ-2020-02-17-1_EN.html).In 2019 and 2020, ECDPM trained EEAS staff in HQ and in EU delegations on strategic and policy-driven programming.ECDPM was swift to produce an analysis of the challenges of scaling up the EU’s global response to COVID-19 (https://ecdpm.org/publications/challenge-scaling-up-european-union-global-response-covid-19/), published only two days after the Commission’s Communication. The paper analyses how the EU managed to swiftly mobilise and repurpose resources to tackle the crisis globally but also highlights shortcomings in the EU response. The paper was picked up and referenced in several newsletters, including the EU Council’s Think Tank Review (https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/44167/ttr_-2020_78final.pdf). ECDPM staff was quoted in several articles of specialised press as questions arose on the scope and (Devex (https://www.devex.com/news/eu-states-kick-the-tires-of-team-europe-plans-98210), Kristeligt Dagblad (https://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/udland/coronakrisen-udfordrer-solidariteten-med-udviklingslande), Devex (https://www.devex.com/news/ngos-see-opportunity-in-merkel-s-financial-transaction-tax-focus-97142)). As part of the analysis, ECDPM published a blog on the need to ensure transparency and accountability in tracking COVID-19 (https://ecdpm.org/talking-points/following-money-why-covid-19-marker-might-not-help/) resources. ECDPM also undertook research and produced a paper on the EU as a global health actor (https://ecdpm.org/publications/fit-purpose-eu-role-global-health-era-covid-19/), identifying the challenges and opportunities in the upcoming programming process to catalyse funds and to strengthen EU action on global health. The paper was largely promoted, also through specialised partners’ network (e.g. Save the children) their network and ECDPM interacted with the accounts which fostered goodwill and exposed the paper to even more people. In 2019-2020, ECDPM continued to build in-house capacity to undertake gender-sensitive research and look at the gender component in upcoming policy processes of particular relevance for this policy process. It published a blog (https://ecdpm.org/talking-points/four-opportunities-gender-importance-deserves-eu-policy-external-spending/) on the importance of gender in EU policy and external spending.ECDPM researched and included the gender dimension in the response to global health in its paper ‘‘Fit for Purpose: The EU’s role in global health in the era of COVID-19’ (https://ecdpm.org/publications/fit-purpose-eu-role-global-health-era-covid-19/).
